PROJECT AT A GLANCE 

 

 

 

  

 

 

  

I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

1. 
I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to  the  Democratic  Socialist  Republic  of  Sri  Lanka  for  the  additional  financing  of  the  National 
Highways Sector Project.1 
 
2. 
The  additional  financing  will  expand  the  current  project’s  output  by  rehabilitating  and 
upgrading  an  additional  62  kilometers  of  national  highways,  comprising  six  link  roads  that 
provide  access  to  the  new  Southern  Highway  in  Western  and  Southern  provinces. 2  The 
Southern Highway is the country’s first controlled-access expressway, and the Colombo–Galle 
section  of  95  kilometers  (km),3 cofinanced  by  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB) 4 and  the 
Japan  International  Cooperation  Agency,  will  become  operational  in  2011.  By  enhancing 
connectivity and reducing access time for the communities served, the proposed improvement 
is critical to ensuring that the development impact of the Southern Highway is optimized and its 
benefits reaped in a timely way. Collectively, the communities served will benefit from improved, 
lower-cost,  and  faster  transport  services  and  thereby  obtain  improved  access  to  economic 
opportunities  and  social  services.  It  will  facilitate  economic  growth  and  contribute  to  reducing 
disparities in Sri Lanka, consistent with the government’s goal of equitable economic growth.5  
 

II. 

THE PROJECT 

A. 

Rationale 

3. 
The National Highways Sector Project, financed with a loan of $150 million from ADB’s 
ordinary capital resources, was approved on 15 December 2005, signed on 14 December 2006, 
and  declared  effective  on  20  February  2007.  The  targeted  outcome  was  improved  national 
highway  transport  efficiency,  and  the  outputs  consisted  of  (i)  providing  policy  and  institutional 
support  and  (ii)  upgrading  270  km  of  core  arterial  national  highways  and  supporting  the 
implementation  of  pilot  performance-based  maintenance  contracts  for  1,500  km  of  national 
highways.  The  project  included  a  component  to  finance  land  acquisition  and  resettlement 
expenditure  for  80  km  of  Colombo  links  toward  implementing  later  the  civil  works,  possibly 
under a future project. 
 
4. 
The project experienced cost overruns during the initial stage of implementation, as the 
cost  of  civil  works  for  the  highway  upgrading  component  exceeded  the  project  appraisal 
estimate  by  128%.6 The  most  significant  cause  was  dramatic  global  price  escalation  for  key 
construction commodities between appraisal in 20057 and the bid preparation in 2008. To meet

component under the current project to 225 km.12

7. 
The  additional  financing  will  scale  up  the  current  project  by  further  expanding  the 
highway upgrading component from 225 km to 287 km. It will help achieve the full extent of the 
improvements envisaged under the original financing by covering additional geographic areas in 
Western and Southern provinces, increasing the number of project beneficiaries, and optimizing 
access  to  the  new  Southern  Highway.  It  supports  the  government’s  priority  to  implement 
improvements quickly  to ensure that  the  development  impact  of  the  new  Southern Highway  is 
optimized  and  its  benefits  are  reaped  in  a  timely  way.  The  project  meets  eligibility  criteria  for 
additional financing. 15 
 
In  keeping  with  the  original  project,  the  targeted  outcome  of  the  additional  financing  is

inclusive  economic  growth.16 The  proposed  additional  financing  is  included  in  the  Sri  Lanka 
country operations business plan, 2011–2013.17

A. 

Technical 

III. 

DUE DILIGENCE 

 

16. 
The  engineering  design  was  based  on  site  condition  surveys  and  field  investigations, 
optimizing  the  required  improvement  works  for  economy  and  construction  efficiency  in 
accordance  with  applicable  international  design  standards.  The  construction  method  will  use 
proven technology with standard materials compatible with local conditions. A road safety audit 
carried  out  during  the  detailed  design  incorporated  findings  and  improvements  wherever 

 possible  to  optimize  horizontal  and  vertical  sign  distances,  improve  visibility  at  intersections, 
provide  warning  signs  for  areas  subject  to  flooding,  and  install  appropriate  warning  signs  and 
markings to slow traffic approaching pedestrian areas, curves, and other low-speed zones. To 
enhance  resilience  to  climatic  hazards  and  disasters,  built-in  civil  engineering  measures  were 
assessed  and  applied,  including  embankment  height,  design  values  of  storm  frequency  and 
runoff,  and  drainage.  Hydrological  considerations  were  heightened  following  consultation  with 
irrigation  and  land  reclamation  authorities.  For  project  road  B157  (a  10.84  km  section  from 
Aluthgama  to  the  Southern  Highway  interchange,  which  is  located  in  a  flood-prone  area), 
concrete pavement was adopted to provide enhanced erosion protection. 
 
B. 

Economic 

The economic assessment was carried out in accordance with ADB's Guidelines for the 
17. 
Economic  Analysis  of  Projects. 21  The  principal  benefits  expected  are  savings  in  vehicle 
operating  costs  and  travel  time.  The  highway  design  and  maintenance  model  was  used  to 
calculate vehicle operating costs and time costs with appropriate input parameters for Sri Lanka. 
With the opening of the Southern Highway in 2011, a substantial increase in traffic is anticipated 
on the link roads included in the project, and benefits to this traffic are included in the analysis. 
The estimated economic internal rates of return (EIRRs) for the  six additional link roads range 
from  14.7%  to  34.7%,  with  an  overall  EIRR  of  23.4%.  The  four  national  highway  roads  in  the 
current project have EIRRs in the range of 14.1%–18.8%. The sensitivity analysis with adverse 
variation  in  project  costs  and  project  benefits22 indicates  that  the  overall  project  has  an  EIRR 
above 12% even with increased costs and reduced benefits. The EIRRs of the roads covered by 
original financing,  additional  financing,  and both  combined are  above 12%,  even  with adverse 
variation  in  costs  and  benefits.  Based  on  the  findings  of  the  economic  assessment,  the 
proposed  improvements  will  have  social  benefits,  such  as  improving  the  availability  of  goods 
and  services,  providing  employment  opportunities,  and  decreasing  poverty.  Therefore,  the 
project is also justified in social cost–benefit terms. 
 
C. 

Governance

Development Authority Act in 1981. Under the Ministry of Ports and Highways (MOPH), RDA is 
responsible for developing and maintaining the national network of class A and B trunk roads. 
RDA is headed by a chairperson who reports to the secretary of MOPH. 
 
19. 
strength to implement the project.23

Financial  management. Financial management assessment was updated for RDA, as 
the  implementing  agency,  and  its  project  implementation  unit.  RDA  has  prior  and  ongoing 
experience  with  implementing  ADB-funded  projects  and  has  satisfactory  capacity  in  terms  of 
project  financial  accounting  and  knowledge  of  ADB  disbursement  procedures.  In  the  project 
implementation unit for the original project, RDA has established a dedicated project accounting 
and  finance  team  with  suitably  qualified  accountants:  a  project  accountant,  an  accountant 
assistant, and four account clerks. RDA will maintain separate project records and accounts to 
identify  the  financing  resources  received  and  expenditures  made  for  the  project,  ensuring  an

Procurement  and  anticorruption.  Goods  and  works  will  be  procured  in  line  with  the 
relevant ADB guidelines, with prior review by ADB at key steps in the procurement process. The 
Bribery Act, No. 11 of 1954 (as amended), the Declaration of Asset and Liabilities Act, No. 1 of

No.  19  of  1994  provide  a  strong  legal  basis  to  deal  with  bribery  and  corruption.  ADB’s

government, MOPH, and RDA. The specific policy requirements and supplementary measures 
are in the project administration manual. 
 
D. 

Poverty and Social 

Poverty  reduction  and  social  impact.  During focus group discussions held  with both 
22. 
men and women, most respondents stated that the proposed road rehabilitation and upgrading 
will  help  create  new  economic  and  employment  opportunities  by  improving  links  to  markets, 
production  centers,  and  other  areas  with  economic  opportunities.  Access  to  public  and  social 
service  facilities  such  as  government  agencies,  health  centers,  and  schools  will  also  be 
improved.24  
 
23. 
Gender.  Women’s  regular  employment  in  the  areas  of  project  influence  is  significant. 
Better roads will ease access to markets, health centers, schools, and workplaces and facilitate 
industrial  development.  Gender  participation  was  ensured  during  project  planning  and  will  be 
further  ensured  during  implementation.  Most  of  the  resettlement  assistants  in  RDA,  who  will 
implement resettlement plans, are women and sensitive to gender concerns. Equal benefits for 
women are expected to be attained under this project. Provisions in bidding documents require 
contractors  to  ensure  that  all  civil  works  comply  with  all  applicable  labor  laws;  do  not  employ 
child labor for construction or maintenance; encourage the employment of the poor, particularly 
women; and do not differentiate wages between men and women, particularly for work of equal 
value. To ensure that these and other gender issues are addressed and complied with, the team 
of construction supervision consultants will include a social development expert. 
 
HIV/AIDS.  Sri  Lanka  continues  to  have  a  very  low  incidence  of  HIV. 25 Based  on  the 
24. 
poverty  and  social  assessment,  the  project  does  not  anticipate  any  risk  of  a  rise  in  HIV/AIDS 
incidence.  Contractors  will  carry  out  HIV/AIDS  awareness  activities  for  laborers  at  work  sites, 
which will be monitored by supervision consultants. 
 
E.

implementation. 
 
26. 
Impact  on  indigenous  peoples.  As  the  poverty  and  social  assessment  found  no 
indigenous  communities  present  in  the  project  influence  area,  no  indigenous  peoples’ 
development plan has been prepared. However, special provisions have been made under the 
resettlement framework and resettlement plans to address impacts on indigenous people. If any 
significant  impacts  on  indigenous  people  are  identified,  an  indigenous  peoples  plan  will  be 
prepared and submitted to ADB for approval. 
 

2. 

Environment 

 
27. 
As  project  roads  are  in  settled  areas  for  most  of  their  length,  with  minimal  forested  or 
natural  habitats,  the  project  has  been  classified  category  B.  Accordingly,  a  consolidated  initial 
environmental  examination  report  with road-specific  environmental management  plans  (EMPs) 
and  environmental  monitoring  plans  (EMoPs)  have  been  prepared  in  accordance  with  ADB's 
Safeguard Policy Statement (2009). All impacts can be managed by adopting suitable mitigation 
measures  described  in  the  initial  environmental  examination  and  road-specific  EMPs  and 
monitored through the EMoPs. EMPs and EMoPs for the construction stage will be incorporated 
in bidding documents and included in contract documents. Anticipated impacts under the project 
are  those  typical  of  road  construction  such  as  the  generation  of  dust,  noise,  and  construction 
waste;  the  temporary  disruption  of  traffic  and  access  to  living  areas  in  and  around  the  work 
areas; and soil erosion from exposed surfaces. The project envisages using borrow and quarry 
sites  already  in  operation;  if  any  new  sites  are  to  be  opened,  the  implementing  agency  will 
ensure that measures described in the EMPs are adopted during site selection and closure, and 
that  approvals  are  obtained  from  the  authorities.  Local  communities  and  other  stakeholders 
were  consulted  during  project  preparation,  and  consultations  will  continue  throughout 
implementation as required. 
 
28. 
RDA  is  responsible  for  ensuring  that  EMPs  and  EMoPs  are  implemented.  The 
Environmental  and  Social  Division  (ESD)  under  RDA  will  monitor  contractors’  environmental 
compliance on behalf of RDA. ESD, which was established through ADB technical assistance,26 
has  been  provided  with  the  necessary  training  and  is  well  experienced  with  ADB's  safeguard 
requirements. However, as ESD is also responsible for managing safeguard activities for other 
ongoing projects under RDA, additional support for regular site monitoring and reporting will be 
provided by the supervision consultant’s team, which includes an environmental specialist. Any 
updates  to  EMPs,  if  required,  will  be  made  by  the  environmental  specialist  consultant  and 
reviewed and approved by ESD. Annual environmental monitoring reports will be prepared and

F. 

Risks and Mitigating Measures 

The key risks include counterpart funding and implementation delay. To mitigate counter 
29. 
funding  delay,  ADB’s  financing  includes  taxes  and  duties  related  to  civil  works  which  will  help 
ease  the  government’s  financial  burden  of  land  acquisition.  To  mitigate  implementation  delay, 
detail  design  and  bidding  documents  have  been  prepared  in  advance  with  the  objective  of 
awarding  the  first  contract  shortly  upon  loan  effectiveness  (footnote  2).  The  overall  risk 
assessment  is  medium  without  mitigation  and  low  with  mitigation.  Integrated  benefits  and 
impacts are expected to outweigh costs. Major risks and mitigating measures are described in 
detail in the risk assessment and risk management plan.27
